Award.AwardTitle: RI: III: Small: IInterlinking Image Collections

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The availability of digital cameras, improved networking, and the diminishing cost of memory has made it easy to capture, share, and store large image collections. With dense sampling, there are many connections and correlations among these captured images, as they effectively record the same or visually similar objects. This project aims to build such networks of linked images on a large scale, store the inter-image relationships in the form of a graph or simplicial complexes called Image Webs, study the properties of these networks, and exploit them for a variety of applications.

Establishing links between parts of images based on image content analysis, and doing so on the scale of millions of images, is a computationally demanding task. Since it is impractical to do this for all image pairs, techniques are developed for attempting to establish links only between pairs for which (1) a link is likely to exist and, (2) the link adds substantially to what is already known about the connectivity of a particular Web. A deeper understanding of the global structure of image webs as topological complexes can aid this link prediction process. Methods are developed for effectively navigating these large structures and for constructing useful maps over them. Integration with more symbolic information associated with images is possible by transferring information around in this vast network.

The project is of a highly interdisciplinary nature, combining techniques from continuous applied mathematics, traditionally used in signal processing and image analysis, with methods from discrete mathematics and network theory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has developed novel methods for interlinking image collections so as to create networks based on (total or partial) similarity of content between the images. Key to the success of the project has been the notion that these Image Webs are not just similarity graphs of images but rather networks where the edges are active transport operators that can transfer information between the images. This transport is accomplished by building function spaces over the images, where the functions encode various image properties and attributes. The edges then correspond to functional maps, or operators that transport functions from one image to another. It turns out that even when the underlying image correspondences are quite complex, the transport operators acting on function spaces are always linear, allowing us to benefit from powerful tools available in linear algebra and optimization.

We have been able to exploit these ideas to build new image co-segmentation algorithms both in the single class and the multi-class cases. The algorithms extract the shared content between the images by looking for fixed points of the above functional transport networks. The co-segmentation algorithms derived from this formulation improve upon the state of the art on all tested standard computer vision benchmark data sets. In fact, though these algorithms are fully unsupervised, their performance frequently exceeds that of their semi-supervised competitors. Partial supervision is easy to incorporate and further improves the segmentation results.

We have also investigated mixed networks of 3D models and images. Such multi-modal networks are especially interesting, as the different modalities capture distinct information about the underlying object. For example, using a small network of 3D models in the same class (e.g., chairs) we are able to take a single image on an object in the same class and do depth inference of quality comparable to a single Kinect scan. As another example, we are able to from a single view of an object to generate image features of the same object from arbitrary views, allowing us to perform view-agnostic image retrieval.

Finally, the project has introduced new theoretical insights in computer vision, based on ideas from functional analysis and homological algebra.
